update.description:
This PR adds support for frame semantics as implemented in [SDFormat PR 560](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/560?w=1). It doesn't add first class support for frames, instead, it resolves poses into frames Gazebo currently expects, i.e., poses relative to parent xml elements in most cases.


## Requirements:
* ~~libsdformat7 [PR 560](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/560?w=1)~~
* libsdformat9 PRs [PR 640](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/640) and [PR 647](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/647)

## TODO:
* ~~Add support for joint axis `expressed_in` attribute.~~
* ~~Add frame semantics for model editor ~~
* ~~Check if saved sdf files preserve frame semantics. This could be by simply storing the transformed poses as opposed to keeping `frames` and `relative_to`s intact. ~~

cc: @{557057:f3a199b9-5784-4964-9644-6ef224bc7dc1}
update.title: Support SDFormat 1.7 frame semantics

content.html: maybe we should make a separate branch / PR for this?

content.raw:
It turns out that the sdf version of the included model was 1.6 and so frame resolution was skipped for it. But since the containing world is 1.7, the model's pose should be able to use frame semantics. My proposed solution is to check if the containing world's DOM was loaded successfully before checking for sdf version. If it was, it doesn't matter what the included model's version is, we can use the model DOM from the world. 

This raises an interesting issue though. If an included model is 1.6, but the world is 1.7, Gazebo is going to load everything as 1.7 and may fail if the included model does not contain a valid 1.7 sdf.
content.html:
It turns out that the sdf version of the included model was 1.6 and so frame resolution was skipped for it. But since the containing world is 1.7, the model's pose should be able to use frame semantics. My proposed solution is to check if the containing world's DOM was loaded successfully before checking for sdf version. If it was, it doesn't matter what the included model's version is, we can use the model DOM from the world.

This raises an interesting issue though. If an included model is 1.6, but the world is 1.7, Gazebo is going to load everything as 1.7 and may fail if the included model does not contain a valid 1.7 sdf.

content.html: I'd like to merge and make a prerelease; we can address further issues in a separate pull request

content.html: hmm, with this fix, ign-gazebo works fine, but Gazebo doesn't. I'm still looking...

content.raw: I have an sdformat fix for this and `//include/pose/@relative_to`. I'll open a PR.
content.html: I have an sdformat fix for this and //include/pose/@relative_to. I'll open a PR.

content.raw: ok, so `//model/pose/@relative_to` works, but `//include/pose/@relative_to` is problematic
content.html: ok, so //model/pose/@relative_to works, but //include/pose/@relative_to is problematic

content.raw: I see the same thing
content.html: I see the same thing

content.raw:
I tried 
```
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"/>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
```
And sdformat throws an exception.
content.html:
I tried 

    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"/>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>

And sdformat throws an exception.

content.raw:
This works inside `<model>` though, just not inside `<include>`:

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <world name="default">
    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
    <model name="M">
      <static>true</static>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="L">
        <visual name="V">
          <geometry>
            <sphere>
              <radius>0.5</radius>
            </sphere>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>
```

![relative_to.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3597364966-relative_to.png)
content.html:
This works inside <model> though, just not inside <include>:

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <world name="default">
    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
    <model name="M">
      <static>true</static>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="L">
        <visual name="V">
          <geometry>
            <sphere>
              <radius>0.5</radius>
            </sphere>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
  </world>
</sdf>

content.raw: yeah, we're not considering `//model/pose/@relative_to` in the world scope
content.html: yeah, we're not considering //model/pose/@relative_to in the world scope

content.raw:
Directly in the world.

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <world name="default">
    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
  </world>
</sdf>
```
content.html:
Directly in the world.

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<sdf version="1.7">
  <world name="default">
    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
  </world>
</sdf>

content.raw:
On a 1.7 SDF file, this places the model on `0 5`, should it be on `5 5`?

```
    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
```
content.html:
On a 1.7 SDF file, this places the model on 0 5, should it be on 5 5?

    <frame name="F_I">
      <pose>5 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
    </frame>
    <include>
      <pose relative_to="F_I"> 0 5 0.4 0 0 0</pose>
      <uri>model://number1</uri>
    </include>
